questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 1:1-1:31 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of 'and God said' and the progression of creation.
tips: Notice the pattern: 'God said, ... and it was so' (v.3) repeats 6 times
Emphasize the phrase 'very good' in verse 31
The word 'darkness' in verse 2 and the light in verse 3 creates a contrast

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (God) does WHAT (creates) in the heavens and earth, WHERE (the universe), and WHY (to establish a good order for His creation).
tips: Include the six days of creation
Note that humanity is created on the sixth day
Mention the declaration of 'very good' at the end

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stands out? Consider: the creation of light (v.3), the formation of humanity in God's image (v.26-27), or the declaration of 'very good' (v.31)?
tips: The light appearing without darkness in the first day shows God's power and order
Humanity being created in God's image is the pinnacle of creation
The phrase 'very good' emphasizes God's satisfaction with His work

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land about God's creation?
tips: The Israelites were in the wilderness after leaving Egypt, so Moses was reminding them of God's sovereignty in creation
This passage establishes God as the ultimate creator and the foundation for their covenant with Him
The 'very good' creation shows God's goodness and is a basis for the covenant

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The six-day creation cycle, the role of the 'seventh day' (rest), or the concept of 'God's image' in humanity?
tips: The six days are a framework for the creation narrative, not literal time periods
Rest on the seventh day (v.31) is a foreshadowing of the Sabbath and the pattern of work-rest
The 'image of God' in humanity (v.26-27) is a unique concept that sets humans apart from other creatures

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the declaration of 'very good' in Genesis 1:31 challenge your view of the world today? What can you do to reflect God's goodness in your community this week?
tips: Consider how your actions (work, relationships) can reflect the order and goodness of creation
Think about how you can be a 'light' in your community as in the first day
Pray for the ability to see the world through God's lens of goodness

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray that God would help you to see the world as He does, and to live in the order and goodness He established in creation.
tips: Thank God for creating the world and for the goodness He sees in it
Ask for the courage to live as a reflection of His image
Pray for the gift of rest and order in your life, as God did in the seventh day

chapters.chapterTitle: The Garden and the First Marriage

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 2:1-25 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'It is not good that the man should be alone' (v.18) and the creation of Eve from Adam's side (v.22).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the Lord God' to emphasize God's active role in creation
Pay attention to the emotional weight of Adam's loneliness and the divine response in verse 18
The phrase 'from the side' in verse 22 shows the intimate connection between man and woman

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God creates, WHAT he does with Adam, WHERE Adam is placed, and WHY God creates Eve.
tips: Include God forming Adam from the dust (v.7)
Note the command for Adam to work and keep the garden (v.15)
Describe the creation of Eve from Adam's side to solve the problem of loneliness (v.21-22)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the creation of Eve from Adam's side (v.22), the command 'You shall not eat of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil' (v.17), or the phrase 'It is not good that the man should be alone' (v.18).
tips: The intimate physical connection in the creation of Eve (a rib) shows the unity of marriage as a divine design
The command about the tree of knowledge sets a boundary that is crucial for human relationship with God
The phrase 'It is not good that the man should be alone' highlights the inherent need for companionship in God's design

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage about the covenant and the divine institution of marriage?
tips: The Sabbath rest in Genesis 2:1-2 is a model for the rest that the Israelites would find in the Promised Land
The marriage covenant (Eve from Adam) prefigures the Church (the Bride) coming from Christ's side
The command not to eat from the tree of knowledge is a covenant of works that the Israelites must uphold

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of the 'image of God' in Adam, the meaning of the tree of knowledge, or the creation of Eve from Adam's side.
tips: In ancient Near Eastern context, the idea of a 'divine image' was not common; this emphasizes the uniqueness of humans and their relationship with God
The tree of knowledge is not about physical knowledge but the knowledge that leads to spiritual separation from God
The rib (a part of the body) shows that marriage is a unity of two beings created by God, not a separate entity

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the divine institution of marriage (as created in Genesis 2) to your relationships this week?
tips: Consider how to honor the sacredness of marriage by building deep, intimate relationships with your spouse
Avoid the temptation of the tree of knowledge by seeking God's wisdom in decisions that affect your relationship with Him and others
Pray for the strength to live in covenant with your spouse as a reflection of God's design

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for creating marriage as a divine institution and for the covenant of works. Ask for wisdom to avoid the tree of knowledge in your relationships.
tips: Thank God for the intimate design of marriage (Eve from Adam's side)
Pray for the Church to be the Bride of Christ, as Eve was from Adam's side
Ask God for the courage to live in covenant with your spouse without sin

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 3:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the serpent's temptation in verses 1-5 and Eve's reaction in verses 6-10.
tips: Notice the serpent's use of 'God says' (v. 1) to imply that God's word is not good
Pay attention to Eve's realization of shame in verse 10: 'The Lord God said...'
The phrase 'the woman' appears 10 times in the chapter, highlighting her role

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (the serpent, Eve, Adam) does WHAT (the serpent tempts Eve to eat the forbidden fruit; Eve and Adam eat; they hide) WHERE (Eden) and WHY (to break the covenant with God).
tips: Include the serpent's lie about God's prohibition (v. 1-5)
Note that Adam and Eve eat the fruit and then hide (v. 8-10)
Mention God's response: curses on the serpent, woman, and ground; and the promise of the seed (v. 14-15)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the serpent's lie (v. 4-5), Eve's shame (v. 7-8), or the promise of the seed (v. 15)?
tips: The serpent's lie: 'You will not die' (v. 4) is a dangerous deception that challenges God's authority
Eve's shame and hiding (v. 8) shows the immediate spiritual consequence of sin: separation from God
The promise of the seed (v. 15) is the first gospel promise that Christ would crush Satan's head

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about the nature of sin and God's response to it through this passage?
tips: The Israelites were entering the Promised Land after 40 years in the wilderness; Moses wanted them to remember that sin has consequences but God's promise of a redeemer remains
This passage foreshadows the need for a Savior for the nation of Israel (and all humanity) because the first sin affected the entire creation
The promise in Genesis 3:15 is the first hint of the coming Messiah

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The identity of the serpent, the meaning of 'the woman's seed', or the curse on the ground?
tips: The serpent is a symbol of evil (the devil) but in the ancient Near Eastern context, serpents were common in the wilderness
The phrase 'the woman's seed' refers to the offspring of Eve (a human) who would be the Messiah (Christ) who would defeat the serpent
The curse on the ground (v. 17) is the consequence of sin: the earth becomes a place of suffering and death

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the reality of temptation and sin (as seen in Genesis 3) affect your life this week? What step can you take to avoid the fall?
tips: Consider a time when you felt tempted to do something that would break your covenant with God (like in Genesis 3, Eve was tempted to doubt God's word)
Think about how the promise of the Seed (v. 15) gives hope for redemption when you are tempted
Pray for the strength to resist temptation, just as Adam and Eve were given a chance to obey God

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the promise of redemption (the Seed) and ask for help to resist temptation.
tips: Thank God that He provided the promise of the Seed (Christ) to redeem us from sin
Pray for the strength to resist the serpent's lies (temptations) in your life
Ask God to help you remember that He is the one who will crush the serpent's head (Christ)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 4:1-16 aloud, focusing on the dialogue between Cain and Abel and the emotional shift from peace to violence.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the LORD' in verses 2, 5, 7, 9, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 16
Pay attention to the emotional tone: from peace (v. 2) to anger (v. 5) to violence (v. 8)
The phrase 'the LORD said' appears 5 times in this range

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize in your own words: WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters for the Israelites entering the Promised Land.
tips: Include Cain's and Abel's offerings (v. 4) and the murder (v. 8)
Note the curse on Cain (v. 15) and the birth of Seth (v. 25)
Highlight the progression from acceptable worship to murder and exile

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you? Consider: Abel's offering (v. 4), Cain's jealousy (v. 5), or the murder (v. 8).
tips: Abel's offering shows faith in God's acceptance (v. 4) - a simple yet profound act of trust
Cain's jealousy (v. 5) is a warning about the internal sin that leads to violence
The murder (v. 8) is the immediate consequence of unaddressed jealousy

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites about God and worship through this story?
tips: The Israelites were entering the Promised Land with their own religious practices; Moses shows that true worship must come from the heart (like Abel) not from self-sacrifice (like Cain)
This story foreshadows the two lines of humanity: the line of Seth (the righteous) and the line of Cain (the wicked)
The curse on Cain (v. 15) warns of the consequences of sin and the need for God's mercy

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? Consider the nature of the offerings, the motivation for murder, and the curse.
tips: The term 'acceptable' (zachar) in Hebrew refers to a sacrifice that is pleasing to God, but the text doesn't specify what made Abel's offering acceptable
Cain's murder (v. 8) is a result of his jealousy, but the text doesn't explicitly state the cause of the murder beyond jealousy
The curse on Cain (v. 15) means he will be a wanderer without a fixed home, but it also affects his descendants (the wickedness of the earth)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does this passage challenge you to live differently this week? Focus on acceptable worship.
tips: When you feel jealous of someone else's success or gifts, ask yourself: 'Am I offering my life to God or trying to make it right by my own works?'
Practice humility by giving your best to God (like Abel) rather than being self-centered (like Cain)
This week, choose one area where you can offer your life to God without condition

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the theme of jealousy and acceptable worship.
tips: Thank God for His acceptance of those who trust Him (like Abel) and ask for help to avoid jealousy
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you see the difference between true worship and self-centered actions
Ask God to protect you from the sin of murder (v. 8) by addressing your jealousy before it leads to violence

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 6:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the corruption of the earth and Noah's grace.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the earth is corrupt' (v.5, 6)
Pay attention to the phrase 'the Lord God' in v.13 showing covenantal promise
The word 'grace' (v.8) is the first use of this term in Scripture

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is responsible for the corruption, WHAT God does in response, WHERE the flood is happening, and WHY God chooses Noah.
tips: Include the 120-year period of wickedness (v.12)
Note that God's decision is based on the corruption of the earth (v.5)
Emphasize Noah's faithfulness and God's grace (v.8,9)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's grief over the corruption (v.6), Noah being 'found' (v.8), or the covenant promise (v.17)?
tips: God's grief shows His deep care for creation
Noah being 'found' is a powerful illustration of grace in the midst of sin
The covenant promise of preservation through the ark is a promise of God's faithfulness

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land about God's response to human sin?
tips: The Israelites were facing a world of moral decay (the Promised Land had been conquered by nations with wickedness)
Moses shows that God's judgment is necessary but also provides a way of escape through faithfulness (Noah)
This passage foreshadows the need for a mediator (Christ) who will save from sin

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of the earth being corrupt (v.5), why God chooses Noah (v.8), or the flood as divine judgment?
tips: The 'corrupt' earth (v.5) refers to widespread moral and spiritual decay, not just physical corruption
Noah is chosen because he was 'righteous' (v.9) and the Lord found him (v.8) in a world of wickedness
The flood is a judgment on sin, but the ark is the means of preservation for life (as a type of Christ)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: In what way can you trust God's grace to preserve you from the corruption of the world this week?
tips: Consider a situation where you feel overwhelmed by sin or corruption
Reflect on how God's grace (like Noah's) can be your refuge
Pray for the courage to trust God in the midst of a corrupt world

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for preserving us through His grace in a corrupt world. Ask for the strength to live righteously.
tips: Thank God for preserving Noah (and us) through His grace
Ask for the strength to live righteously in a corrupt world
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help us trust God's promises

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 7:1-24 aloud, focusing on the command to build the ark (v.1-2) and the flood's progression (v.10-17).
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the LORD' (v.1, 7, 10)
Pay attention to the word 'ark' (v.1, 3) and how it's described as 'a very large ship' (v.16)
Note the emotional shift from obedience (v.1-2) to the flood's impact (v.10-17)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God commands to build the ark, WHAT happens, WHERE the ark is built, and WHY God sends the flood.
tips: Include that Noah is the only one who obeys (v.1-2)
Note that the ark is built on the earth (v.16) and the flood covers the entire earth (v.24)
Describe the reason: God's judgment on sin (v.1-3)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the command to build the ark (v.1-2), the 40 days of rain (v.11), or the animals boarding the ark (v.8-9)?
tips: Noah's obedience: 'This is what I have done' (v.1-2) shows immediate action
The 40 days of rain (v.11) is a sign of God's judgment and the beginning of the flood
The animals entering the ark (v.8-9) shows God preserving life despite the judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land about God's relationship with His people through this flood narrative?
tips: This passage shows God's judgment on sin (the entire earth) and His preservation of the righteous (Noah and his family)
It points to the need for obedience to God's commands (as the Israelites were entering the Promised Land after 40 years of wandering)
The flood is a symbol of the need for a new beginning and the covenant with God's people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The 40 days of rain, why God chose Noah, or the significance of the animals in the ark?
tips: The 40 days of rain (v.11) is a sign of God's judgment, but the passage says the flood lasts 150 days (v.24) for the waters to cover the earth
Why God chose Noah? Because he was blameless (v.6) and God had been with him (v.10)
The 7 pairs of every kind of animal (v.9) is a way to preserve life for the new creation, not a literal 7 pairs for every kind

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of obedience to God's command in your life this week, even when it's difficult?
tips: Consider an area where you need to trust God's plan (like Noah trusting the flood)
Think about how God has preserved you through a hard time (like the flood preserving Noah)
Practice obedience by taking one step of trust this week, as Noah did

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His judgment on sin and His preservation of the faithful. Ask for courage to obey His commands when it's hard.
tips: Thank God for preserving Noah and his family through the flood
Pray for the strength to trust God when circumstances are difficult
Ask God to help you be like Noah in obedience

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 8:1-12 aloud, focusing on the receding waters and the birds' messages.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the waters recede' (v.1, v.4)
Pay attention to the dove's return with an olive leaf (v.11)
The raven's role as a sign of the flood's end (v.7)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who God is working with, what God does, where it happens, and why God does this (for the waters receding).
tips: Noah sends out the raven and dove
The dove returns with an olive leaf showing the waters have abated
Noah sees dry ground and the people exit the ark

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the dove returning with an olive leaf (v.11), Noah removing the ark's covering (v.13), or God's promise (v.21)?
tips: The olive leaf is a sign of new life and hope after the flood
Noah's action of removing the ark's covering shows he sees the dry ground
God's promise of never again flooding the earth is a lasting covenant

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage about God's faithfulness and promise?
tips: God remembers His covenant with Noah and keeps His promise
The flood was a punishment, but God promises to never repeat it
This shows God's patience and mercy

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of the olive leaf, the timing of the promise, or the concept of God's covenant with the earth?
tips: The olive leaf symbolizes hope and renewal, not a literal olive tree
The promise of 'never again' is a covenant that God will not flood the earth, but the earth still faces problems
Covenant in Hebrew (berit) means a binding agreement, so God makes a new covenant with the earth

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you trust God's promise of a dry land (peace) when you feel the waters are rising (challenges)?
tips: Identify one area where you feel overwhelmed and pray for God's promise to dry it
Remember the olive leaf as a sign of hope and trust God's promise to provide
This week, take action that shows you're stepping out of the flood into the dry land

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His promise to never flood the earth again. Ask for courage to trust His promises in your life.
tips: Thank God for the promise that He will never again curse the ground with flood
Pray for strength to trust His promises when life feels like a flood
Ask God to help you see the dry land (hope) in your current situation

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 9:1-27 aloud, focusing on the covenant language and the emotional shift in the story of Noah becoming drunk.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'this is the sign' (v.13)
Pay attention to the contrast between God's blessing and the curse on Canaan (v.24-27)
The phrase 'the blood of your life' (v.4) appears in the command

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God is dealing with, WHAT He commands, WHERE this happens, and WHY He establishes the covenant.
tips: Include Noah's role as the representative of humanity after the flood
Note that God commands the prohibition of blood and capital punishment for murder
Describe the rainbow as the sign of the covenant

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the rainbow sign (v.13), the blood prohibition (v.4), or the curse on Canaan (v.24-27)?
tips: The rainbow is a unique sign that connects the sky and earth, showing God's promise to never flood again
The command 'do not eat the blood' emphasizes the sanctity of life and the connection between life and death
Noah's curse on Canaan is a prophetic statement that affects future generations, showing God's judgment on sin

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land about God's covenant with creation?
tips: This covenant includes all humanity and the earth, so the Israelites are part of God's new creation
The rainbow sign is a reminder of God's patience and the opportunity for repentance
The blessing on Shem points to the Messiah (Jesus) who will come from Shem's line

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The blood prohibition? The curse on Canaan? The rainbow sign?
tips: Blood in ancient cultures represented life; the prohibition ensures that life is not wasted and that the person who takes blood is responsible for the life
The curse on Canaan is a bit complex because Canaan is the ancestor of the nations that would later be in the land of Canaan, but God's curse is on the entire line of Canaan
The rainbow is a sign that God will not flood again, but it also points to the covenant that God will not destroy the earth by water again

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the sanctity of life (from the blood prohibition) apply to your life this week? What can you do to honor God's design for life?
tips: Consider how you treat others and animals; avoid actions that harm life
Think about your relationship with food and the importance of not consuming blood
Pray for the courage to live without taking blood (in the sense of not taking life in a way that is unjust)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for His covenant with all creation and ask for the strength to live according to His commands.
tips: Thank God for the rainbow as a sign of His promise
Pray for the courage to live without taking blood (in the sense of respecting life)
Ask God to help you understand the curse on Canaan and how it relates to your life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 10:1-32 aloud, paying attention to the structure of the genealogical lists and the repetition of 'the sons of...'
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'These are the descendants of...' for each son of Noah
Pay attention to the listing of the maritime peoples under Japheth (e.g., the Erythraei and Gergashites)
The phrase 'the land of Canaan' and 'the land of Egypt' appear multiple times

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (the descendants of Noah), WHAT they did, WHERE they settled, and WHY this genealogy matters for the Israelites entering the Promised Land.
tips: Include: Shem's line (which includes Abraham), Ham's line (Canaan and Egypt), Japheth's line (maritime nations)
Note: The land of Canaan is the specific land that the Israelites would enter, so it's a direct connection to their future
The genealogy shows the spread of nations after the flood, setting the stage for the Israelites to enter a land already inhabited

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part of this genealogy stood out most? Consider: the listing of the land of Canaan (v. 15-16), the kingdom of Nimrod (v. 8-10), or the maritime nations under Japheth (v. 2-7)?
tips: The land of Canaan is the specific land that the Israelites would enter, so it's a direct connection to their future
Nimrod's role as the founder of the city of Babel (Babylon) shows the beginning of human civilization and the city states that would later become powerful
The maritime nations under Japheth (like the Erythraei) represent the global spread of humanity through the sea

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this genealogy?
tips: This passage shows that the land of Canaan (where the Israelites were going) was already populated by descendants of Ham, which is why God had to bless the Israelites through Abraham (Shem's line)
It emphasizes that all nations come from one man (Noah) and that God's providence is at work in the spread of nations
The genealogy sets the stage for the Israelites to understand that they are part of a global story that begins with Noah and leads to Abraham

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this chapter are challenging to interpret? Consider the genealogy, the meaning of specific names, or the historical context.
tips: The genealogy lists many names that are not well-documented in the ancient world; it's a way to show the spread of nations without being too detailed

The term 'Canaan' in this context refers to the land and its people, but the Israelites were to inherit it as a blessing from God (so it's not the land of Ham's descendants in the sense of being the o
Nimrod is a figure from the pre-flood era who is listed as the founder of cities, which shows the beginning of human civilization and the city states that would later become centers of power

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the diversity of nations in this genealogy remind you of the unity of humanity? What practical step can you take this week to honor God's diversity in your community?
tips: Remember that all nations come from one man (Noah) and that God has blessed them through different lines
This week, reach out to someone from a different cultural background and share a meal or a conversation
Pray for unity in your community and for God to use the diversity of cultures to build His church

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the unity of humanity and the diversity He created. Ask for wisdom to live in a way that honors the nations He has blessed.
tips: Thank God for creating a world of diverse nations from one family (Noah)
Pray for the unity of the church across cultures and for the Israelites to live in harmony with the nations around them
Ask God to help you to see the value in every culture and to use your gifts to build up the body of Christ

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 12:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'I will make you a great nation, and I will bless you, and I will make you a blessing for all the earth' (v.2-3) and the immediate response 'So Abram went' (v.4).
tips: Notice the repetition of God's promises with 'I will' (v.2-3)
Pay attention to the emotional tone: God's call is both sovereign and personal
Note the phrase 'the land that I will show you' (v.7) which indicates God's guidance

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God calls, WHAT He promises, WHERE Abram goes, WHY God calls him, and HOW Abram responds.
tips: Include that Abram leaves Ur of the Chaldeans (v.4)
Note the promise of blessing all nations (v.3)
Describe Abram's immediate obedience (v.4)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the promise of blessing all nations (v.3), Abram's immediate obedience (v.4), or the phrase 'the land that I will show you' (v.7)?
tips: The promise of blessing all nations is the most profound and universal theme
Abram's immediate obedience (v.4) shows faith without delay
The phrase 'the land that I will show you' indicates God's guidance and revelation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage?
tips: This passage establishes the foundation for the Israelite identity: God calls individuals to a purpose and promises blessing through obedience
The promise of blessing all nations (v.3) is the basis for the covenant that includes the Israelites and the future Church
Moses is showing that God's faithfulness to Abram prefigures His faithfulness to the Israelites

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The call to leave his country and kindred, the promise of blessing all nations, or the phrase 'the land that I will show you'?
tips: In the ancient Near East, migration was common, but God's call to Abram was unique because it was for a specific purpose (blessing all nations)
The phrase 'blessing for all the earth' (v.3) is a universal promise that seems large for a single person, but it is fulfilled through Christ (Gal 3:16)
The phrase 'the land that I will show you' (v.7) indicates that God will reveal the land to Abram at the right time, not immediately

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of divine call and promise in your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you are called to leave your comfort zone and trust God's promise
Reflect on a specific promise God has made to you and how you can act on it
This week, take one small step of obedience as Abram did (v.4)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His promise to bless you and for calling you to a purpose. Ask for the courage to obey.
tips: Thank God for the promise of blessing all nations (v.3) and for His faithfulness to Abram
Pray for courage to leave your comfort zone and trust God's timing
Ask God to help you understand the land He will show you (v.7) as you follow Him

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 13:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the tension in verses 7-8 and the divine reassurance in verses 14-18.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the land' (v.1, 4, 7) to emphasize the limited space
Pay attention to Abram's generous offer: 'Let me choose the land for you' (v.5) - shows his willingness to give up his claim
Emotional tone shifts from tension (v.7-8) to divine reassurance (v.14-18)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Abram and Lot), WHAT (separating their herds due to land conflict), WHERE (the land of Canaan), and WHY (to avoid conflict and maintain God's covenant promise).
tips: Include Abram returning from Egypt with a large herd (v.1-2)
Note the conflict over territory (v.7-8)
Describe Lot's choice of the Jordan plain (v.9-10) and God's reaffirmation of the promise (v.14-18)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Abram's offer to let Lot choose first (v.5), Lot's choice of the Jordan plain (v.9-10), or God's promise (v.14).
tips: Abram's offer to let Lot choose first (v.5) shows his generosity without condition
Lot's choice of the Jordan plain (v.9-10) warns about the dangers of worldly allurements (Sodom's destruction)
God's promise: 'all the land that you see will belong to your offspring' (v.14) reaffirms the covenant

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage?
tips: Consider that the Israelites were about to enter the land God promised to Abraham, so Moses reminds them of God's covenant and the danger of worldly choices
God's promise is secure and abundant, but the Israelites must live by faith, not by sight (the land of Canaan is the promised land, but they must not be drawn to sin like Lot)
This passage foreshadows the need for the Israelites to trust God's provision and avoid the pitfalls of the world

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? Why did Abram and Lot separate when they were both in the same land? What does 'the land' refer to? Why did God reaffirm the promise after Lot left?
tips: They were both in the land of Canaan, but Abram had just returned from Egypt with a large herd (v.2), so the land was limited and conflict arose
'The land' in v.1 refers to the Promised Land (Canaan) that God had given to Abraham
God reaffirmed the promise to ensure that Abram's descendants would inherit the land, even though Lot had chosen a land that would later be destroyed (Sodom)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice generosity over greed this week? Consider giving up something you value for the sake of others.
tips: Be generous with your time (e.g., help a neighbor without expecting anything in return)
Avoid the temptation of worldly success (like choosing the easiest path, even if it leads to destruction)
Reflect on what you can give up this week that would help others or honor God

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His promise to Abraham and for His faithfulness to His covenant. Ask for courage to be generous and to avoid worldly allurements.
tips: Thank God for His promise to Abraham and for His faithfulness to His covenant
Pray for the courage to be generous and to avoid the pitfalls of worldly allurements
Ask God to help you choose the right path (like Lot's choice) that leads to blessing, not destruction

chapters.chapterTitle: Abram Rescues Lot and Meets Melchizedek

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 14:1-20 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the four eastern kings and the five Canaanite kings in verses 1-3, and the unique title of Melchizedek in verses 18-20.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the king of Sodom' (v.10) and 'Abram' (v.13) as key identifiers
Pay attention to the title of Melchizedek: 'king of Salem' (v.18) and 'priest of God Most High' (v.18)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the four eastern kings, Abram, Melchizedek, and the king of Sodom) is involved, WHAT happens (the defeat of the five Canaanite kings, Abram's rescue of Lot, and the encounter with Melchizedek), WHERE it occurs (the region of the Canaanites, likely near Sodom), and WHY Abram rescues Lot (to save his family and possessions from the invaders).
tips: Include the defeat of the five Canaanite kings by the four eastern kings
Note that Abram musters 318 trained men and pursues the invaders
Highlight the encounter with Melchizedek and the tithe

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Abram's pursuit (v.4-6), Melchizedek's blessing (v.18-20), or the tithe (v.20)?
tips: Melchizedek's role as both king and priest of God Most High is unique and foreshadows Christ
The tithe from Abram to Melchizedek shows a voluntary offering of gratitude and recognition of God's sovereignty
Abram's refusal of the king of Sodom's offer (v.20) demonstrates his trust in God alone

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land about God's victory and leadership?
tips: This passage shows that God is the ultimate source of victory and provision, not human strength
The priesthood of Melchizedek (a type of Christ) emphasizes God's eternal and universal authority
Abram's refusal of worldly rewards points to the Israelites' need to rely on God, not on their own might

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The identity of the kings, the meaning of 'tithe', or why Abram refuses the king of Sodom?
tips: The four eastern kings (v.1) are likely the coalition of kings that included Chedorlaomer (the Amorite king) and others, but their exact identities are not specified in detail

In ancient Near Eastern context, a 'tithe' (10%) was a common tax, but here Melchizedek is a priest of God Most High, so the tithe is a voluntary act of worship and acknowledgment of God's sovereignty
Abram's refusal of the king of Sodom's offer (v.20) is significant because it shows that God's victory was not earned by human effort and that Abram's loyalty was to God alone

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does Abram's refusal of worldly rewards apply to your life? What situation requires you to trust God alone?
tips: Consider an area where you might be tempted to seek personal gain or recognition
Think about how you can give thanks to God for His provision without seeking worldly rewards
Practice declaring God's role as the source of your victory and provision

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His victory and leadership. Ask for courage to trust Him alone in difficult circumstances.
tips: Thank God for providing victory through Him alone, not through human might
Pray for the strength to recognize God's role in your life and to offer Him the first fruits
Ask God to help you refuse worldly rewards when He is the true source of victory

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 15:1-21 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between God and Abram in verses 1-6 and the covenant ceremony in verses 10-18.
tips: Notice Abram's response 'Here I am' (v. 1) and his questioning about offspring (v. 2)
Pay attention to the phrase 'as many as the stars in the sky' (v. 5) and how it expresses the vastness of God's promise
Note the emotional shift from Abram's doubt to his faith in God's promise (v. 6)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT God promises, WHERE this covenant is established, and WHY God makes this covenant with Abram.
tips: Include the promise of descendants as numerous as the stars (v. 5)
Note that Abram believes God's promise (v. 6) and is credited as righteous
Describe the covenant ceremony with the animal pieces (v. 10-18)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Abram's faith (v. 6), the promise of descendants (v. 5), or the covenant ceremony (v. 10-18)?
tips: Abram's faith is credited as righteousness (v. 6) - a powerful example of justification by faith
The promise of descendants as numerous as the stars (v. 5) - a picture of God's abundant provision beyond human understanding
The covenant ceremony where God passes between the animal pieces (v. 10-18) - a unique and visible sign of God's commitment to the land

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage?
tips: This passage establishes that God's covenant with Abram is the foundation for the Israelites' identity and land inheritance
It emphasizes that God's promise is based on faith (not works) and is a guarantee of the land from Egypt's river to the Euphrates (v. 18)
The covenant is a living promise that God will be their shield (v. 1) and provide for them

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of righteousness by faith, the animal sacrifice ritual, or the promise of land to Abram?
tips: In ancient Near Eastern context, covenant rituals involved cutting animals in two (as in Exodus 24), but here God passes through the pieces to show His commitment
The phrase 'as many as the stars' (v. 5) is a way to express the vastness of the promise without counting (a common Hebrew idiom)
Righteousness by faith (v. 6) means that Abram's faith was counted as righteousness by God, which is the basis for Paul's teaching in Romans 4

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Abram's faith (v. 6) in your life this week? What promise from God do you need to trust in when it seems impossible?
tips: Identify one area where you are doubting God's promises (like the promise of descendants) and pray for faith
Practice trusting God's provision even when you don't see the outcome (like Abram trusting God would give him descendants)
Reflect on how God is your shield (v. 1) and how He will provide for you

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being Abram's shield and for the covenant promise. Ask for faith to trust His promises when they seem impossible.
tips: Thank God for being the covenant-keeper and for His promise to provide descendants
Pray for the courage to trust God's promises in your life, even when the outcome is not yet visible
Ask God to help you believe that He will be your shield and provider

tips: Notice the phrase 'the God who sees me' (v.13) repeated in Hagar's declaration
Pay attention to the contrast in tone: Sarai's desperation (v.1-2) vs. the Angel's comfort (v.7-13)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Sarai, Abram, Hagar, the Angel of the LORD), WHAT (Sarai gives Hagar to Abram to bear children, Hagar becomes pregnant and flees, the Angel intervenes and promises), WHERE (the desert), and WHY (Sarai's barrenness and the need for children).
tips: Include Hagar's pregnancy and her flight to the desert (v.5)
Mention the Angel of the LORD's promise to Hagar (v.10-13)
Note that Ishmael is born later (v.15)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Hagar's cry 'the God who sees me' (v.13), the promise of a nation (v.15), or the Angel's command to return and submit (v.9).
tips: Hagar's declaration shows she has found God in her suffering, which is a powerful reminder of God's presence in the marginalized
The promise of a nation through Ishmael foreshadows the future of the Israelites, even though it's through a servant

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land about God's character and response to suffering?
tips: This passage addresses the Israelites' own struggles with barrenness and the need for God's intervention in their lives
It shows that God works through human weakness and the promises He makes to those who are in distress

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of Sarai's action, the nature of the Angel of the LORD, and the promise to Hagar versus Sarah.
tips: Sarai's action was a desperate measure to have children, common in ancient times when barrenness was a social issue
The Angel of the LORD is a pre-incarnate appearance of Christ, showing God's direct care for the afflicted
The promise to Hagar is that her son will be the father of a nation (the Ishmaelites), which is distinct from the promise to Sarah (Isaac's line)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of 'God who sees' from this passage: What situation requires you to trust God's provision when you feel overlooked?
tips: Identify a situation where you feel unseen and ask God to reveal your needs
Pray for the courage to trust God's promises when you are in a place of hardship

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for seeing your struggles and providing a way out. Ask for the strength to trust Him in the desert of your life.
tips: Thank God for seeing your struggles and providing a way out
Ask for the courage to be like Hagar who seeks God in the desert

Notice the promise of Isaac in verse 20

tips: Include the name changes: Abraham and Sarah
Note the promise of Isaac as the heir
Mention the immediate circumcision of the household

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the name change to Abraham (v.5), the promise of Isaac (v.20), or the sign of circumcision (v.11-14).
tips: The name change from Abram to Abraham signifies a new identity in God's plan
The promise of Isaac as the heir shows God's faithfulness despite human inability
The sign of circumcision is a permanent mark of commitment to the covenant

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land about the covenant through this passage?
tips: The covenant is a living relationship that requires active participation (as seen in the sign of circumcision)
The promise of Isaac reminds the Israelites of God's faithfulness to their ancestors
The name changes (Abraham and Sarah) signify a new identity in God's plan for the nation

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The significance of circumcision, the meaning of 'El Shaddai', and the promise of Isaac in Abraham's old age.
tips: Circumcision in this context is a sign of the covenant, not a ritual for the body alone
'El Shaddai' (God Almighty) emphasizes God's power to provide and fulfill promises
The promise of Isaac was a sign that God's promises are reliable even when it seems impossible

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you live out the covenant of circumcision in your life this week? Consider a step of commitment to God.
tips: Think about a time when you need to 'circumcise' your heart (i.e., commit to God)
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you become a new creation (like the covenant renewal)
Take a small step of obedience this week, such as sharing your faith or living out the promise of Isaac

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the covenant and the promise of Isaac. Ask for courage to live by the covenant.
tips: Thank God for His faithfulness to Abraham and the promise of Isaac
Pray for the courage to live by the covenant (as in circumcision: a permanent sign of commitment)
Ask God to help you become a new creation through the Spirit

tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I have taken her' (v.2) to show the initial claim
Pay attention to Abimelech's confession of innocence (v.7-8) and his fear (v.9)
The phrase 'my son' (v.12) when Abraham admits his fear

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (Abraham, Abimelech, Sarah), WHAT (Abraham's deception and its consequences), WHERE (Gerar), and WHY (Abraham's fear of being killed for Sarah's sake).
tips: Include Abraham's claim that Sarah is his sister (v.1-2)
Note Abimelech taking Sarah (v.2-3) and God's warning in a dream (v.4-6)
Highlight the restoration of Sarah (v.9-10) and Abraham's admission of deception (v.11-12)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Abimelech's dream warning (v.4-6), Abraham's admission of deception (v.11-12), or Abraham's intercessory prayer (v.13-15).
tips: Abimelech's dream warning: God's immediate intervention to prevent injustice
Abraham's admission of fear: humble confession despite the risk of death
The intercessory prayer: modeling of seeking God's help for others

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land about God's character and the consequences of human failure?
tips: God's protection of the promised lineage despite Abraham's failure
The importance of integrity in leadership (Abimelech's eventual restoration of Sarah)
Divine grace in healing the situation through prayer (Abraham's intercession)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The cultural context of claiming a sister, the dream warning, or the resolution of the situation.
tips: In ancient Near East, claiming a sister as a wife was a common way to avoid polygamy and was culturally acceptable (v.1-2)
The dream warning (v.4-6) shows God's authority over the king's actions, not just a random intervention
Abimelech's initial taking of Sarah (v.2-3) was a cultural norm, but God's intervention prevents the injustice

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you seek God's protection in a situation where you feel your integrity is at risk this week?
tips: When you are tempted to lie, ask God for wisdom to avoid the situation
Pray for courage to be honest with those in authority over you
Practice intercessory prayer for the leaders in your life, as Abraham did for Abimelech

tips: Thank God for protecting the promised lineage through Abraham's failures
Pray for the integrity of those in authority over you
Ask God to help you intercede for others in need

questions.title: Read Aloud

tips: Notice the repetition of 'Here I am' (vv. 1, 7, 11)
Pay attention to Isaac's innocent question in verse 8
The emotional shift when the angel stops the sacrifice (v. 12)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is tested, WHAT God commands, WHERE it takes place, and HOW Abraham responds.
tips: Include the three-day journey to Moriah (v. 2)
Note Isaac carrying the wood and Abraham preparing the fire and knife (v. 2)
Describe the angel's intervention and the ram caught in the thicket (vv. 12-13)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Abraham's obedience (v. 3), Isaac's trusting question (v. 7), or 'God will provide' (v. 8, 14)?
tips: Abraham's immediate response 'Here I am' shows unwavering trust
Isaac's innocent question about the lamb highlights childlike faith
The ram caught in the thicket symbolizes God's provision in unexpected ways

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land about God through this test of Abraham?
tips: This passage shows God's commitment to provide for His people through faithful obedience
Abraham's willingness to sacrifice his son demonstrates the cost of true faith
The covenant promise in verses 15-18 reassures future blessing through obedience

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The command to sacrifice Isaac? Why God 'tests'? The ram appearing at the last moment?
tips: 'Testing' in Hebrew (nissah) means proving faith, not tempting to sin
Child sacrifice was common in Canaan but God's command shows His uniqueness
The ram 'caught in a thicket' represents God's provision that is both unexpected and sufficient

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Abraham trusted God even when it didn't make sense. What situation requires you to trust God's provision this week?
tips: Consider an area where you're holding back from full obedience
Think about something precious you need to surrender to God
How can you practice 'rising early' in obedience like Abraham? (v. 3)

questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He provides. Ask for Abraham-like faith to trust and obey even when it's costly.
tips: Thank God for providing Jesus as the ultimate sacrifice
Pray for courage to obey in difficult circumstances
Ask God to strengthen your trust in His provision for your specific needs

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 23:1-16 aloud, paying attention to the emotional weight of Sarah's death and Abraham's resolve.
tips: Notice the phrase 'Sarah died' (v.1) is stated with gravity and finality
Pay attention to the emotional weight of Abraham's grief (v.2) and his resolve (v.4)
The phrase '400 shekels of silver' (v.7) is a specific amount that shows the significance of the purchase

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (Abraham, Ephron, Hittites) does WHAT (purchases a burial site), WHERE (Hebron), and WHY (to secure a burial ground for Sarah and his future family).
tips: Include that Sarah died at age 127 in Hebron (v.1)
Note the negotiation with Ephron the Hittite (v.4-6)
Highlight the payment of 400 shekels of silver (v.7-10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Sarah's death (v.1), Abraham's insistence on the cave of Machpelah (v.6), or the payment of 400 shekels (v.7-10)?
tips: Abraham's immediate response to Sarah's death: 'I will go to the Hittites and purchase a burial site' (v.2) shows his urgency and faith
The phrase 'the cave of Machpelah' (v.6) is a specific location that becomes the first promised land in Abraham's possession
The 400 shekels of silver (v.7) is a significant amount that demonstrates the value of the land and the seriousness of the transaction

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage?
tips: This passage shows that God's promises are secured through faith and action, even in the face of death and uncertainty
The purchase of the cave of Machpelah establishes the first legal possession of the Promised Land by Abraham, which the Israelites would later inherit
It demonstrates that the land God promises is not only for physical inheritance but also for spiritual and eternal purposes (Heb 11:13-16)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The cultural context of burial practices, the meaning of 'cave of Machpelah', or the payment of 400 shekels?
tips: In ancient Near Eastern culture, burial sites were often purchased to avoid being buried in the same place as the dead (v.4-5)
The term 'Machpelah' (v.6) means 'the double cave' and is a specific burial site in Hebron
The 400 shekels of silver (v.7) was a large sum, equivalent to about 1000 days of a common laborer's wage, showing the significance of the transaction

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of faith in God's promises for burial and inheritance. What area of your life requires you to trust God's provision for a permanent solution this week?
tips: Consider an area where you feel you are 'buried' (e.g., unresolved issues, past mistakes) and how God's promises can provide a permanent solution
Think about what you are willing to 'pay' (with time, resources, or even your peace) to secure a place of rest and hope
How can you take a step of faith to 'purchase' a solution for your needs, just as Abraham did?

questions.title: Prayer

tips: Thank God for the promise of a permanent home (the land) for His people
Ask for the courage to trust God's provision in the midst of life's uncertainties
Pray for the strength to secure a place of rest and hope in your life through faith

Pay attention to Rebekah's family background and her immediate willingness to go (v.15)

Note Rebekah's family agreement and her immediate decision to leave

questions.title: Best Bit

questions.title: Main Point

The servant's faithfulness (as a picture of the Spirit) leads to the Church being gathered by God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The servant's test of Rebekah, the cultural context of marriage in the Negev, and the term 'negev' (the land).
tips: The servant's test (v.12-15) was to ensure Rebekah was from Abraham's family and not a Canaanite, which was a common practice in that time
The term 'negev' refers to the southern part of Canaan, which was the land God had promised to Abraham
The idea of a 'bride' for Isaac being chosen by the servant reflects the covenant nature of the marriage, not a random selection

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you seek God's guidance for a decision this week, as the servant did, with the same faithfulness and trust in God's provision?
tips: Choose one decision where you need to trust God's provision (e.g., a relationship, career, or financial matter) and pray for clarity
Practice the servant's discipline of seeking God's guidance before making a decision
Like Rebekah, be willing to act on God's provision without delay

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's guidance to find a bride for your life (like Isaac) and for the willingness to go with Him (like Rebekah).
tips: Thank God for providing a wife for Isaac (a picture of the Church for Christ)
Pray for the courage to follow God's lead in your decisions
Ask God to help you be like Rebekah and act quickly when He calls you

questions.instruction: Read Genesis 28:10-22 aloud, focusing on the ladder dream (v.10-12) and Jacob's response (v.13-22).
tips: Notice the recurring phrase 'ladder' (v.10) and the angels ascending and descending (v.12)
Pay attention to Jacob's emotional reaction when he wakes (v.13): 'He was afraid and trembling'
Listen for the significance of 'Bethel' (v.19) as 'the house of God'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize who (Jacob), what (dreamed and woke), where (Bethel), and why (to reaffirm God's covenant and promise).
tips: Include Jacob's dream of the ladder from earth to heaven with angels (v.10-12)
Note God's appearance and Jacob's vow to serve (v.13-22)
Mention the naming of the place Bethel (v.19)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the ladder dream (v.10-12), God's words (v.13-14), or Jacob's vow (v.20-22).
tips: The ladder dream represents the connection between heaven and earth, which is a powerful metaphor for God's presence
Jacob's immediate response of naming the place 'Bethel' shows his recognition of God's presence
The vow of service (v.20-22) is a concrete step of commitment in the face of God's promise

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage?
tips: This passage reaffirms the Abrahamic covenant and God's promise to Abraham (v.13-14)
For the Israelites entering the Promised Land, it shows God is present and active in their journey
The ladder image foreshadows Christ as the true ladder (John 1:51) that connects heaven and earth

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The ladder dream, the meaning of 'Bethel', or Jacob's vow?
tips: The ladder is a metaphor for the connection between heaven and earth, which is a new concept for the Israelites
In Hebrew, 'Bethel' (bth-el) means 'house of God', but Jacob names it after the dream (v.19) to show his recognition of God's presence
Jacob's vow of service (v.20-22) is a commitment that will be fulfilled in the future, as the Israelites are entering the Promised Land

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you set up a 'pillar' of your own by naming a place where you've experienced God's presence and making a vow to serve Him?
tips: Identify a moment when you felt God's presence (like Jacob's dream)
Make a small vow to serve God in a specific area for the coming week (e.g., prayer, service)
Write down the place and vow to remember it as your 'Bethel'

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His presence and ask for the strength to build a 'pillar' of faith in your life.
tips: Thank God for the presence of His Spirit in your life (like Jacob's dream)
Ask for the courage to make a vow of service to Him
Pray that Christ will be your true ladder (the way between heaven and earth)

Pay attention to Jacob's careful planning with the animals (vv.37-43)
The emotional shift from Rachel's jealousy to God's intervention

questions.title: Summary

tips: Include the birth of Dan and Naphtali through Bilhah
Note the birth of Gad and Asher through Zilpah
Highlight God remembering Rachel and her birth of Joseph

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Rachel's pregnancy (v.19), Jacob's cunning strategy (vv.37-43), or God's promise to Rachel (v.23)?
tips: Rachel's pregnancy is a sign of God's favor and her deep longing
Jacob's strategic use of animals shows wisdom in business and faith
The birth of Joseph as the firstborn of Rachel is significant for the tribe of Judah

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land about the importance of God's blessing through family and strategy?
tips: The twelve tribes are God's chosen people, and their formation is a testament to God's faithfulness
Jacob's success with Laban shows that God can work through human strategy when aligned with His will
The passage foreshadows the coming of Christ through the tribe of Judah

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The birth order and tribal assignments, the meaning of 'speckled and spotted' animals, or the rivalry between Rachel and Leah?
tips: The birth order in Genesis 30 is complex; the sons are listed by their mothers to show the rivalry
'Speckled and spotted' refers to the color patterns of animals that breed more effectively for prosperity
Rachel's initial jealousy (v.1) shows the human struggle with God's timing

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'Prospering through cunning' (but in a godly way) this week? Focus on strategic planning that honors God.
tips: Identify a situation where you can use your resources wisely to honor God
Consider how your family or community can benefit from strategic planning
Pray for wisdom to align your plans with God's purposes

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's blessing on your family and for the courage to trust in His timing, like Rachel.
tips: Thank God for the promise that He remembers those who are faithful
Pray for strength to endure when things don't go as expected
Ask God to help you trust in His provision for your family

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 31:1-52 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tension in Jacob's departure and Rachel's actions.
tips: Notice the phrase 'I have seen' appears in verses 1, 2, and 29
Pay attention to the quietness of Jacob's departure in verses 1-5
The phrase 'God is with me' (verse 29) appears twice in the chapter

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is moving, WHAT they are doing, WHERE they are going, and WHY they are leaving.
tips: Include Jacob's decision to flee after hearing God's command (v.1)
Note that Rachel steals the household gods (v.18)
Mention the covenant at Mizpah (v.49-50)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jacob's secret departure (v.1-5), Rachel stealing the household gods (v.18), or God's warning to Laban in the dream (v.24-25).
tips: Jacob's quiet departure shows his trust in God despite Laban's hostility
Rachel's action of stealing the idols is a bold act of rebellion but also a way to protect her family from Laban
The dream warning is crucial because it shows God's protection for Jacob even in Laban's pursuit

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage?
tips: This passage shows that God's protection and covenant are active even when leaving a situation of deception and conflict
It reassures the Israelites that God will provide for them and protect their identity as a people
The covenant at Mizpah (v.49-50) is a sign of God's ongoing care for the Israelites

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The household gods, why Jacob fled, or the covenant at Mizpah.
tips: Household gods (hekalot) were sacred objects in Canaanite worship, and Rachel's theft was a way to preserve her family's identity without Laban's control
Jacob's decision to flee was prompted by God's command (v.1) and Laban's hostility (v.2) which he felt was a threat to his family
The covenant at Mizpah involved a ritual where they set up a stone (v.49) and a blessing (v.50) to mark their separation and mutual protection

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Jacob's trust in God to flee from a difficult situation this week?
tips: Consider a situation where you feel trapped by circumstances (like Laban's hostility) and God has a plan for you to leave
Practice being 'quiet' in your departure, like Jacob, without seeking to fight back
When you feel your 'household gods' (beliefs, relationships) are being threatened, take a step to protect them by trusting God

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for providing a way out of difficult circumstances and ask for courage to leave a hostile situation.
tips: Thank God for providing a way out of difficult circumstances
Ask for courage to leave a situation that is hostile to your identity
Pray for God to help you keep your 'household gods' (your faith) safe when you flee

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 32:1-32 aloud, paying attention to the tension between Jacob's fear and his prayer in verses 27-28, and the physical struggle in verses 24-25.
tips: Notice Jacob's desperate prayer: 'O God... I have been with you' (v.27-28)
Pay attention to the man's touch of Jacob's hip (v.25) as a physical manifestation of the struggle

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE and WHY (the context of Jacob's fear and the encounter with God).
tips: Include Jacob sending messengers to Esau (v.1-3)
Note Jacob dividing his camp and praying desperately (v.27-28)
Describe the wrestling with the divine being at night until dawn (v.24-30)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jacob's prayer (v.27-28), the physical struggle (v.24-25), or the new name 'Israel' (v.28)?
tips: Jacob's prayer shows desperate faith when facing Esau's threat
The man's touch of the hip dislocating it (v.25) symbolizes the cost of transformation
The new name 'Israel' (v.28) means 'he who strives with God' and marks a new identity

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage?
tips: True identity comes through wrestling with God, not through our own efforts
The new name 'Israel' foreshadows the people of God transformed by grace
This passage encourages embracing God's transformation even when it's painful

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The identity of the man, the meaning of the new name, or the significance of the hip dislocation?
tips: The man's identity: In this context, it is God (YHWH) appearing in human form
The name 'Israel' is a new identity resulting from the struggle, not Jacob's own actions
The dislocation of the hip (v.25) represents the pain of becoming 'Israel'

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply Jacob's wrestling with God to your life this week? Specifically, how do you 'strive' with God in prayer?
tips: Identify a situation where you feel God is testing your faith (like Jacob's fear of Esau)
Practice a prayer of desperation like Jacob's (v.27-28) when you feel stuck
Ask God to help you embrace the cost of transformation in your life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about Jacob's wrestling with God: Thank God for the new identity He gives us through Christ. Ask for the courage to wrestle with Him when things get tough.
tips: Thank God for the new name 'Israel' which means we are transformed by His grace
Pray for the strength to let go of our own control and trust God's provision
Ask God to help you become a 'striver' in prayer when facing fear and doubt

tips: Notice Jacob's seven times bowing (v.3) and the weeping together (v.4)
Pay attention to Esau's initial refusal of gifts (v.5) and later acceptance (v.10)
The phrase 'El-Elohe-Israel' (v.20) is a key declaration of God's presence

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe who (Jacob and Esau) does what (reconciles after years of separation), where (in the land of Canaan), and why (to restore family ties and settle in the Promised Land).
tips: Include Jacob's seven times bowing and the weeping
Note Esau's change of heart: initially refusing gifts but later accepting them
Mention Jacob's decision to settle at Succoth and build the altar at Shechem

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jacob's seven bows (v.3), the weeping (v.4), Esau's offer to travel (v.10), or the naming of the altar (v.20)?
tips: Jacob's seven times bowing shows deep humility and reverence
The weeping together is a powerful moment of shared grief and reconciliation
The name 'El-Elohe-Israel' (v.20) declares God as the God of Israel, emphasizing divine presence

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage?
tips: This passage shows reconciliation with enemies is possible through divine grace
The Israelites needed to see that God can restore relationships and establish worship in the land
The altar at Shechem (El-Elohe-Israel) is a sign that God is the God of their new home

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? Why does Jacob bow seven times? Why does Esau initially refuse gifts? What does 'El-Elohe-Israel' mean?
tips: Bowing seven times was a gesture of deep respect and humility, common in ancient Near Eastern cultures
Esau's initial refusal might be due to his anger over the previous conflict, but he later accepts because of the emotional reunion
El-Elohe-Israel means 'God of Israel' (the people of God), emphasizing God's personal involvement with Jacob's family

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of reconciliation. What situation in your life requires you to reach out and reconcile with someone this week?
tips: Think about a relationship that has been strained and how you can show humility like Jacob
Consider the importance of God's grace in reconciliation (as seen in Esau's embrace)
How can you build a place of worship in your life (like Jacob at Shechem) through community?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His grace in reconciliation. Ask for courage to forgive and embrace others.
tips: Thank God for His grace that brings reconciliation
Ask for courage to forgive and embrace others as Esau did
Pray for God to help you build a place of worship in your community

tips: Notice the repetition of 'circumcision' as the condition for marriage (v.15)
Pay attention to the emotional shift from Shechem's desire (v.1) to the sons' deceitful agreement (v.15) and the sudden violence (v.25)
The phrase 'they were killed' (v.25) is stark and emphasizes the consequences

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved (Shechem, Hamor, Jacob's sons), WHAT happens (the rape of Dinah, the negotiation, the violent response), WHERE (in the land of Canaan), and WHY (to protect the family from Canaanite influence).
tips: Include the key event: Simeon and Levi's deception about circumcision and their violent response
Note that Jacob's sons are the ones who act, but Jacob is the one who rebukes them later
The context of the Canaanite culture and the covenant sign (circumcision) is critical

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Shechem's initial desire for Dinah (v.1), the sons' deceitful agreement (v.15), or the violent response (v.25-29)?
tips: Shechem's declaration: 'I will be your son-in-law' (v.1) shows his immediate desire without hesitation
The sons' clever but dangerous plan: agreeing to circumcision as a sign of the covenant (v.15) that they later use to justify violence
The suddenness of the violence: 'they were killed' (v.25) without warning, showing the cost of their deception

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land about the dangers of assimilation and the importance of maintaining distinct identity?
tips: This passage warns that the Israelites must not be tempted to assimilate with the Canaanites, as seen in the misuse of the covenant sign (circumcision) by the sons
The violence shows that internal corruption (from a foreign culture) can lead to destructive actions, which is why the Israelites were to remain separate
Moses emphasizes the need for vigilance in maintaining the covenant and the identity of God's chosen people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The sons' deception about circumcision, the cultural context of Canaanite practices, and the violent response of Simeon and Levi.
tips: Circumcision was a covenant sign for the Hebrews (Genesis 17), but in this context, the Canaanites also practiced it. The sons used it as a condition for marriage, which is a sign of the covenant but
The term 'defilement' (v.1) refers to the sexual violation, which is a severe spiritual and physical contamination
The violence in this chapter is extreme but was a response to the perceived threat of assimilation and the violation of Dinah, which was a direct attack on the family and the covenant

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you avoid the danger of assimilation and the misuse of covenant signs in your life? Consider the theme of maintaining distinct identity in a mixed culture.
tips: Identify one area where you might be 'circumcised' (i.e., making a covenant) but then use it for something harmful
Ask: What would happen if I were to act like Simeon and Levi? How can I be more careful with my commitments?
This week, reflect on a time when you felt the need to protect your identity or values from being compromised

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the covenant that protects us from assimilation. Ask for strength to resist the temptation to compromise our identity for the sake of convenience.
tips: Thank God for the covenant that protects us from being assimilated
Ask for strength to resist the temptation to compromise our identity for the sake of convenience
Pray that the Holy Spirit will help us recognize when we are being 'defiled' by foreign practices

The list of Edomite kings (v.30-46) illustrates the temporal prosperity of Edom without the covenant promise
The statement that Edom becomes a nation before Israel (v.40) highlights the contrast with Jacob's line

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage about the relationship between Esau's descendants and the covenant promise?

Note the separation of lines as a divine plan that has been carried out (v.40)
This passage reassures the Israelites that they are the chosen line, not the Edomites

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The term 'Seir', the list of Edomite kings, and the phrase 'the land cannot support both'.

The chapter lists 21 kings of Edom (v.30-46) - this is a long list that might be confusing to follow without context
The phrase 'the land cannot support both' (v.2) is a divine statement about the land's capacity, not a human judgment

questions.title: Application

Pray for wisdom to choose the path that leads to the promised land (the covenant)
This week, seek to follow the path that is aligned with God's promise, not worldly success

questions.title: Prayer

Pray for the courage to choose the path of the promise over worldly success
Ask God to help you see the difference between temporal prosperity and the covenant promise
