questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 43:1-34 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Joseph and the brothers in verses 26-34.
tips: Notice the phrase 'I am Joseph' (v. 27) which is a declaration of identity
Pay attention to the emotional shift from fear to relief in the brothers' reactions (v. 29-30)
The repeated phrase 'my father' (v. 28, 30) shows the brothers' connection to their father

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Joseph and the brothers) does WHAT (sends Benjamin with gifts to Egypt; Joseph tests them with a feast), WHERE (Joseph's house in Egypt), and WHY (to show God's provision for the brothers and their loyalty to Jacob).
tips: Include the fact that Jacob sent Benjamin with double money and gifts (v. 8)
Note that the brothers were seated in birth order (v. 29) and Benjamin received five times the food (v. 30)
Joseph's recognition of Benjamin (v. 26) was the turning point

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Joseph's recognition of Benjamin (v. 26-27), the seating in birth order (v. 29-30), or Benjamin receiving five times the food (v. 30-31).
tips: Joseph's immediate recognition of Benjamin (v. 26) shows his deep knowledge of the family
The brothers being seated in birth order (v. 29) is a sign of Joseph's trust and the brothers' respect for their father's order
Benjamin receiving five times the food (v. 30) is a clear sign of special favor and God's provision

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land about God through this passage?
tips: This passage shows that God provides for His people in unexpected ways, even when they are in a state of fear and confusion
The feast prepared by Joseph pictures the gospel feast that God provides for those who trust Him
The special treatment of Benjamin (the youngest son) foreshadows Christ as the ultimate blessing for the church

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The command to send Benjamin with double money? Why does Joseph have a feast? The phrase 'five times more' for Benjamin?
tips: The 'double money' (v. 8) refers to the extra money the brothers had to pay for the grain, but in this context, it was a sign of their submission to Joseph's authority
Joseph's feast (v. 30-31) is a test of the brothers' loyalty and their ability to trust in God's provision
The phrase 'five times more' (v. 30) is a sign of Joseph's favor, but in the context of the brothers' fear, it was a way to show that God had already provided for them

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you let go in faith and trust God's provision this week, like the brothers who sent Benjamin with their gifts?
tips: Consider an area where you are holding back from trusting God's provision
Think about how you can be the 'Benjamin' in your life, receiving God's special favor
Practice being seated in the order of God's will (birth order) by following the sequence of events in your life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His provision and ask for the courage to trust in His plan, like the brothers who were tested by Joseph.
tips: Thank God for providing for His people in the midst of hardship
Ask for the courage to trust Joseph's leadership (like God's leadership) when you face uncertainty
Pray for the gift of special favor (like Benjamin) in your life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 44:1-34 aloud, focusing on the emotional dialogue between Judah and Joseph in verses 22-23.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I will go' (Judah says: 'I will go' in v. 22) and 'the boy' (Benjamin) is emphasized multiple times
Pay attention to the anguish of the brothers and Judah's passionate plea for Benjamin

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the brothers and Joseph), WHAT (Joseph discovers the cup in Benjamin's sack and declares Benjamin will be a slave), WHERE (in Joseph's house in Egypt), and WHY (the brothers' fear for Benjamin's life).
tips: Include the key event: Joseph discovering the cup in Benjamin's sack (v. 19-20)
Note Judah's role: he intercedes for Benjamin (v. 22-23)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Judah's plea for Benjamin (v. 22-23), the emotional intensity of the brothers' anguish (v. 20-21), or the substitutionary sacrifice (v. 22).
tips: Judah's words 'I will go instead of the boy' (v. 22) show immediate and willing sacrifice
The phrase 'the boy' (Benjamin) is used with deep emotion, showing Judah's love for his brother
This plea foreshadows Christ's substitutionary atonement

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land about the importance of self-sacrifice for the vulnerable?
tips: This passage shows that God's people must be willing to make costly sacrifices for one another
It emphasizes that true faithfulness involves intercession and self-sacrifice for the vulnerable
The passage points to Christ, the Lion of Judah, who would be the ultimate substitute

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? Joseph's initial anger, the meaning of 'the boy', and the role of the steward.
tips: Joseph's anger is a result of his past betrayal and the cup being found in Benjamin's sack
The term 'the boy' (Hebrew: 'alman') emphasizes Benjamin's youth and vulnerability
The steward discovered the cup and brought the brothers to Joseph, which is why they were in the house

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of substitutionary sacrifice: What can you do this week to be a substitute for someone else?
tips: Think of a situation where you can take on a burden for someone else (like a friend in need)
How can you show love for a vulnerable person by taking responsibility for them?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the example of Judah's selfless love and ask for the courage to be a substitute for others.
tips: Thank God for the example of Judah's sacrifice
Ask for the courage to be a substitute for others in your life
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you understand the depth of Christ's sacrifice

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 45:1-28 aloud, paying attention to Joseph's emotional revelation and the brothers' reaction.
tips: Notice Joseph's weeping (v.1) and the brothers' terror (v.3)
Pay attention to the phrase 'I am Joseph' (v.1) and how it contrasts with the brothers' fear
Notice the repetition of 'God sent me before you to preserve life' (v.8) as the key explanation

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is revealed, WHAT Joseph does, WHERE it occurs, and WHY he does it (to preserve life).
tips: Include Joseph revealing himself to his brothers (v.1-3)
Note the brothers' fear and Joseph's reassurance (v.4-5)
Describe Joseph's explanation of God's purpose (v.8) and the urgency to bring Jacob (v.11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Joseph's emotional revelation (v.1), his explanation of God's purpose (v.8), or his urging to bring Jacob (v.11)?
tips: Joseph's declaration 'I am Joseph' (v.1) - the moment of identity after 22 years of separation
The phrase 'God sent me before you to preserve life' (v.8) - the profound meaning of divine providence in suffering
Joseph's immediate action to bring Jacob (v.11) - showing his commitment to the family's restoration

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage of Joseph's revelation?
tips: This passage reassures the Israelites that God's purpose in their past suffering (the enslavement) is for their future restoration (the Promised Land)
Joseph's story shows that God works through suffering to bring about family reconciliation and preservation of life (v.8)
The Israelites are part of God's plan from the beginning (the promise to Abraham) and this story is a sign of God's ongoing provision

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The timing of Joseph's revelation, the meaning of 'preserve life', or the brothers' initial terror?
tips: The phrase 'God sent me before you to preserve life' (v.8) refers to the preservation of the entire Israelite family through the famine and the provision of food in Egypt
In the cultural context of Egypt, Joseph's revelation would have been a shock because he was the one who sold his brothers into slavery (v.1-3)
The brothers' terror (v.3) is understandable given their past actions and the power of Joseph as a ruler

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you take a step to restore trust and reconciliation in a family or relationship this week, inspired by Joseph's message that God preserves life through suffering?
tips: Think about a situation where you feel God's purpose in your suffering is leading to restoration
Consider how you can act with the same urgency as Joseph to bring healing (e.g., by reaching out to someone who is hurting)
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you see God's purpose in your current struggles

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the restoration of family through Joseph's revelation and ask for courage to reveal yourself in reconciliation.
tips: Thank God for preserving your life and family through His purpose (as Joseph did)
Pray for courage to be the 'Joseph' who reveals yourself to others in a time of conflict
Ask God to help you see His purpose in your suffering and to act in reconciliation

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 46:1-26 aloud, focusing on the emotional weight of Jacob's response to God's promise and the reunion with Joseph.
tips: Notice Jacob's declaration 'Here I am' (v.1) as a response to God's promise
Pay attention to the phrase 'the LORD has made me a great nation' (v.4) - God's promise of blessing
Listen to the weeping and embrace between Jacob and Joseph (v.29-30) - the emotional impact of reunion

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jacob and his household) does WHAT (moves to Egypt), WHERE (Goshen), and WHY (to fulfill God's promise of a great nation and temporary sojourning).
tips: Include the divine assurance from God at Beersheba (v.2-3)
Note the reunion with Joseph (v.29-30)
Mention the instruction to tell Pharaoh they are shepherds (v.33)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the list of the seventy souls (v.26), the weeping and embracing (v.29-30), or Joseph's instruction to tell Pharaoh they are shepherds (v.33)?
tips: The 70 souls represent God's universal plan for all nations, which is a powerful reminder of God's covenant
The weeping and embracing show the depth of the relationship between father and son, and the cost of separation
Joseph's instruction to be shepherds is a strategic move to ensure their safety in Egypt without causing suspicion

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage?
tips: The passage reassures the Israelites that God is with them in their temporary sojourn (Egypt) and will bring them back to the Promised Land
It emphasizes that God's plan includes all nations (the 70 souls) through Jacob's seed, showing the universal scope of God's promise
The reunion with Joseph and the instruction to be shepherds demonstrate that God's promises are being fulfilled even in the midst of foreign lands

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The temporary sojourning in Egypt, the significance of the 70 souls, or the instruction to tell Pharaoh they are shepherds?
tips: The phrase 'great nation in Egypt' (v.4) is temporary sojourning, not permanent settlement (the Israelites were in Egypt for generations before returning to the Promised Land)
The number 70 (v.26) corresponds to the 70 nations in Genesis 10, showing God's plan for all peoples through Jacob's seed
Telling Pharaoh they are shepherds (v.33) is a strategic move to avoid suspicion and to have a safe place in Egypt (Goshen) without being seen as a threat

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: The passage shows that God's people are in temporary sojourning but with a divine promise. What situation requires you to trust God's provision this week, even when it's temporary?
tips: Identify one area where you are in a temporary situation (like in Egypt) and pray for God's guidance to move in the direction He has for you
Practice being a 'shepherd' in your current circumstances by being humble, trusting, and seeking God's provision for your needs

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His promises and ask for courage to trust Him in temporary circumstances.
tips: Thank God for His promise that He will make Jacob a great nation (v.4) even in temporary sojourning
Pray for courage to trust God in your current temporary situation (like in Egypt)
Ask God to help you be part of the 70 souls that represent His universal plan for all nations

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 47:1-26 aloud, paying attention to the emotional shift from Jacob's blessing of Pharaoh to the urgency of the famine.
tips: Notice the phrase 'your father and your brothers' (v.1) which shows Joseph's leadership role
Pay attention to the emotional tone in Jacob's blessing of Pharaoh (v.3) and his final request for burial in Canaan (v.29-30)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jacob, Joseph, Pharaoh, and the Israelites) does WHAT (Joseph presents family to Pharaoh, Jacob is given Goshen, Joseph collects money, livestock, and land), WHERE (Egypt), and WHY (to survive the famine and secure the future for Israel).
tips: Include the event of Jacob's blessing of Pharaoh (v.3)
Note Joseph's collection of money, then livestock, then land (v.14-16)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jacob's blessing of Pharaoh (v.3), the establishment of the one-fifth law (v.16), or Jacob's final request for burial in Canaan (v.29-30).
tips: Jacob's blessing of Pharaoh (v.3) shows a reversal of roles: Pharaoh becomes a blessing from Jacob
The one-fifth law (v.16) is a practical solution that ensures both Pharaoh's needs and the people's survival
Jacob's insistence on burial in Canaan (v.29-30) expresses faith in God's promise despite being in Egypt

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage?
tips: This passage shows that God's provision in Egypt was for the long-term good of the Israelites, even in a crisis
The hope of Canaan (the Promised Land) is secured through Joseph's leadership and God's promise

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The one-fifth law (v.16)? Why Joseph collects land (v.14-16)? Why Jacob insists on burial in Canaan (v.29-30)?
tips: The one-fifth law (v.16) might seem harsh but it's a practical measure to ensure the land remains productive for future generations
The concept of 'collecting land' (v.14-16) is a cultural shift from the typical land ownership in Egypt, showing Joseph's wisdom
Jacob's request for burial in Canaan (v.29-30) is challenging because it's a physical act of faith in a land that is not yet promised in the current context

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does this passage's theme of 'Hope beyond Egypt' (divine provision in crisis) apply to your life this week?
tips: When facing a crisis, trust God's provision even when it seems temporary
Identify a place where you need to have hope beyond your current situation

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for providing in the midst of famine, ask for courage to trust His provision, and pray for hope beyond Egypt.
tips: Thank God for providing for us in the midst of famine
Pray for courage to trust God's provision when it's hard to see
Ask God to help us remember that our ultimate hope is in Canaan (the Promised Land)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 48:1-22 aloud, paying attention to the tension in Jacob's hands and the emotional response of Joseph.
tips: Notice the phrase 'I have made you' (v10) which shows Jacob's confidence in God's plan
Pay attention to Jacob's crossing of hands (v10) and Joseph's protest (v12-13)
Listen for the phrase 'Ephraim will be greater than Manasseh' (v13)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it takes place, WHEN it happens, and WHY Jacob does it.
tips: Include the three main characters: Jacob, Joseph, and Ephraim/Manasseh
Note that Jacob is old and about to die (v1)
The blessing happens in the field (v1) as Jacob prepares to die

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jacob's crossing of hands (v10), his declaration about Ephraim being greater (v13), or the final blessing statement (v22).
tips: Jacob's crossing of hands shows God's sovereignty in choosing the younger son for blessing
The phrase 'Ephraim will be greater than Manasseh' (v13) is a bold statement that defies natural order
The final declaration: 'In you, Israel will pronounce blessings' (v22) points to the future identity of the nation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land about God's sovereign choice through this blessing?
tips: This passage reassures the Israelites that God's promises are fulfilled in the future through His sovereign choice
The blessing of the younger son (Ephraim) foreshadows the Church (the 'younger' branch) being the greater in the future kingdom
Moses emphasizes that God's plan for Israel is not based on natural order but on His will

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? Why does Jacob cross his hands? What does 'double portion' mean? What does 'Israel' refer to in v22?
tips: In ancient Israel, the hand blessing was a sign of the elder son receiving the blessing. Jacob's crossing of hands shows God's sovereignty overriding natural order
The 'double portion' is a special blessing that would have been given to the tribal leader (like the high priest), but here it's for Ephraim (the younger son)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you trust God's sovereign choice in your life, even when it seems to defy natural order?
tips: This week, identify a situation where you are the 'younger' or less favored (e.g., in a team, family, or faith journey) and pray for God to give you the confidence to trust His plan
Consider how God might be calling you to be the 'Ephraim' in your life (the one who will be greater in the future)
Practice 'crossing your hands' in your heart by trusting God's choice over your own expectations

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His sovereign choice in blessing the younger son, and ask for courage to trust His plan in your life.
tips: Thank God for choosing you (the younger) in His plan
Ask for the strength to trust God's blessing even when it seems counterintuitive
Pray that God will use you to be the 'Ephraim' in your community

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 49:1-33 aloud, paying attention to the phrases that describe each son's blessing and the burial command.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the scepter shall not depart from Judah' (v.10) - a key messianic promise
Pay attention to the emotional tone in Judah's blessing: 'the obedience of the peoples' (v.10) suggests hope for a future ruler who brings order
Note the contrast between Reuben (v.3-4) and Judah (v.10) - Reuben's sin causes him to lose the firstborn status

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe who (Jacob) gives prophetic blessings to his twelve sons, what (the blessings that anticipate each tribe's future), where (in the land of Canaan), and why (to prepare the Israelites for the Promised Land).
tips: Include Reuben's sin leading to loss of preeminence (v.3-4)
Note Simeon and Levi's scattering due to violence (v.23-24)
Highlight Judah's blessing as the key to the messianic line (v.10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider Judah's blessing (v.10), Joseph's blessing (v.22-26), or the burial command (v.29-33)?
tips: Judah's blessing: 'the scepter shall not depart from Judah until Shiloh comes' (v.10) - the most messianic and forward-looking
Joseph's blessing: 'the blessing of the house of Judah' (v.22) - shows the importance of the tribe of Judah
The burial command: Jacob instructs to be buried in Machpelah (v.29-33) - a powerful symbol of continuity with the patriarchs

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage?
tips: This passage sets the future for the tribes, emphasizing Judah's preeminence as the line of the Messiah
It reminds the Israelites of the consequences of sin (Reuben, Simeon, Levi) and the hope for the future (Judah)
The burial in Machpelah (v.29-33) shows the continuity of the covenant and the promise to Abraham

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The messianic prophecy in Judah (v.10)? Why Judah is the scepter? The burial command in Machpelah?
tips: The phrase 'the obedience of the peoples' (v.10) might be hard to interpret - it refers to the nations being obedient to the Messiah
The scattering of Simeon and Levi (v.23-24) is a warning about the consequences of violence, which the Israelites might have forgotten
The burial in Machpelah (v.29-33) is a specific location that might be confusing because it's not in the Promised Land but in Hebron

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to a specific theme from this passage: the consequences of sin or hope for the future. What can you do this week?
tips: Reflect on how your actions might cause others to lose preeminence in their lives (like Reuben)
Pray for the hope that comes from Judah's blessing - that God will bring order and peace in your life
Consider the burial command: How can you leave a legacy that is in line with God's promises?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of Judah's preeminence and hope for the future.
tips: Thank God for the promise that the Messiah will come from Judah
Pray for courage to trust in God's timing (like Judah's blessing)
Ask God to help you avoid the sins that lead to scattering (like Simeon and Levi)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Genesis 50:1-26 aloud, paying attention to Joseph's emotional response and the brothers' fear in verses 18-20.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'you meant evil against me, but God meant it for good' (v. 19)
Pay attention to Joseph's weeping and reassurance (v. 18-20)
The phrase 'the bones of Joseph' (v. 25) emphasizes the promise to carry his remains

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Joseph and his brothers), WHAT (mourn, embalm, carry Jacob to Canaan for burial), WHERE (in Egypt, then to Canaan), and WHY (to fulfill Jacob's request and reconcile with brothers).
tips: Include Joseph's mourning and embalming of Jacob (v. 2-3)
Note the brothers' fear and Joseph's reassurance (v. 18-20)
Describe the promise to carry Joseph's bones to Canaan (v. 25)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Joseph's reassurance (v. 19), the brothers' fear (v. 18), or the promise to carry Joseph's bones (v. 25).
tips: Joseph's words 'You meant evil against me, but God meant it for good' (v. 19) - it's a profound summary of God's providence
The brothers' fear turning to hope after Joseph's reassurance (v. 18-20) - shows reconciliation
The promise to carry Joseph's bones to Canaan (v. 25) - ties the promise of land to future generations

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Moses trying to communicate to the Israelites entering the Promised Land through this passage?
tips: Reassure the Israelites that God's plan for them (the Promised Land) is secure, even though they faced past conflicts with Joseph
Show that God turns human evil into good (as in the brothers' actions) for the greater good of the future
Emphasize that the promise to Abraham will be fulfilled through Joseph's descendants

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'God meant it for good', why Joseph had to go to Canaan for burial, and the significance of carrying bones to Canaan.
tips: 'You meant evil against me, but God meant it for good' (v. 19) - God uses human actions (even evil) for His purposes
The burial at Machpelah (Canaan) is significant because it was the land promised to Abraham (Gen 15:18-21), so Joseph's body will be buried there
The promise to carry Joseph's bones to Canaan (v. 25) is a sign that the Israelites will inherit the land

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice the hope that God turns evil into good in your current situation this week?
tips: Identify a recent situation where you felt like you were in a place of evil (e.g., conflict, failure) and pray for God's provision
Make a promise to someone (like a family member) to be a blessing as God works in their life
Write down one specific way you can trust God's provision this week, just like Joseph trusted God for his brothers

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for turning evil into good and ask for courage to trust His provision.
tips: Thank God for turning the brothers' evil intentions into Joseph's blessing
Pray for courage to trust God's provision when you feel like you are in a difficult situation
Ask God to help you carry the 'bones' of your faith (your life) to the Promised Land
